cons: They wanted to switch to work from home with one mo notice and right to inspect my home, require me to have hard line internet, require I drop off all equipment at a location of their choosing within 48 hours if I quit. They constantly complain people are doing things wrong without giving any options for written guidance or access to support on the weekend and overnight shift. Management couldn't do the most basic tasks, such as understanding that you can't assign people to work any shift with no notice (i.e. someone has worked 8-4:30 for months, you can't just put them on the schedule for next week starting at 6 unless they have a formal availability submitted stating they can work other hours)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chicago, IL
pros: Working with the children. They are so intelligent and appear to persevere even after all they have been through. Many of these clients come here after going through traumatic situations and still find a way to strive. All they want to do is be kids, and at Aunt Martha's we have been able to provide them that opportunity. Staff really shows that they care for these children as if they are their own, whether it be tough love after bad decisions or a hug and a shoulder to cry on when needed most.
cons: Upper management needs a lot of work. They over run their employees who are working for little play. They don't know much of what is going on in the company in terms of knowing each individual client's situation. They don't act as if they care to get to know their situations. I believe this would help to better serve these children, if management can understand what the children are going through, they can better provide access to services they need. There is no consistency, things are changing on a daily basis, no one is on the same page.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Chicago, IL

job_title: Youth Specialist II in Chicago, IL

job_title: Medical Biller in Tinley Park, IL
pros: Loved their causual dress code.  You could wear Jeans everyday!
cons: Management is very unorganized!  I was hired for one position, & they totally had me doing a job in which I have never done before!  Literally 0 experience!  And the person training me was a big bully!!  Management should make sure that Every one is on the same page, training wise.  Very rude coworker's and Managers also.  Right down to the "Big Bosses"  Very unhealthy place to work. They run their head quarters & clinics very poorly!  Miscommunication,  training & just overall atmosphere is just plain ghetto!  Never have I worked at a place where your co workers spoke to each other in a different language & talked about co workers while they were standing right there in the same office together, and nothing was done about it! They would also scream at each other, ready to fight all the time, & Nothing was done about it!  Seriously a big joke working there!  Worse job ever!

review_title: AMYSC- mission is way better than Senior Health and Senior Management
job_title: Health Manager in Chicago Heights, IL
pros: The work that front line staff reaches communities an people who normally dont have access to nice healthchare.  You will build an amazing and desperate need for an us versus them lifestyle.  You will form bonds that will help you push through the poor decisions made from outside the clinic setting.  One thing for sure, if you can work here, your next job will be way more fulfilling and easier, aunt marthas will suck every ounce of blood and sweat out of you, and then dismiss you to save themselves.
cons: Senior Health Mgmt and Senior Mgmt have no commitment to the employees, providers, and those who really help the clinics function.  A lot of turnover up top as each tries to jockey for position and lie there way through the CEO's requests, demands, and strategies.  The Senior Health Mgmt, have members who verbally cant relate to staff, have counter engagement personas, and dont work at developing teams

review_title: Go with another choice, if possible.
job_title: Case Manager in Park Forest, IL
pros:
--a job with a steady paycheck
--kind coworkers
--some training available (i.e. breastfeeding training by CEDA) that is paid for the company
--mileage compensation
cons:
Everything was exciting the first few months when I started working here. Unfortunately, reality hit shortly after, and I developed a deeper understanding of the company.

--low pay (other companies tend to pay more in this industry in this state and county)
--high stress and unmanageable/unrealistic workload (leads to burnout!)
--very high turnover
--seemingly questionable stability (some locations and programs shut down without much notice)
--there is heavy priority for quantity that quality tends to be sacrificed
--not enough time or resources for case managers to adequately help clients (affects client retention)
--no program budget
--some great benefits and trainings have been cut out (i.e. tuition reimbursement, diversity trainings, etc)
--no matching or contribution to retirement (403-b)
--not much room to grow in the company through advancement or compensation ------2% max annual raise but they are so behind,you won't actually see your raise  until 5-6 months later

job_title: Community Health Promoter/Enrollment Specialist in Rockford, IL
pros: This company has excellent benefits with paid time off with vacation, sick bank, absence and holiday pay.   They offer a variety of health insurance plans along with dental and eye.  They also give you life insurance, long term disability and short term disability.  The team I work with is awesome, always there to help,  It is nice to be at a job where you are appreciated and thanked for the outcome.  The pay is average, but again haven't been here that long so I also need to show them that I do make a difference for their company, and at the end, it will all pay off for all the hard work and dedication.
cons: There is just one thing that I wish they had and that is a matching contribution to our 403 or 401k retirement or  even a pension plan, I think implementing this would make all employees be long-term with no turnaround in employees.

job_title: Clinical Staff in Aurora, IL
pros: I had a great supervisor and got great clinical experience
cons:
Their "per encounter" system for patient visits, regardless of length or complexity, encouraged turnstile care, malpractice, and providing phony "care" to every family member in the room to pad billing and productivity numbers

Employees kept who were unethical, unprofessional, dishonest and incompetent provided they could push enough warm bodies through

Thieves literally. I would have my lunch clearly labeled with my name. People would take it, eat half, and put back the rest. I had to keep my kleenex, pens, paper, etc under lock and key

Very anti teamwork, very lord of the flies. Different departments and supervisors would undermine each other.

The facilities were terrible. Very inadequate space and poorly kept. The employee kitchen was always filthy, with bugs, dirty dishes, etc. The bathrooms were like gas station bathrooms. No parking. Employees forced to park on street or in nearby lots all of which had parking meters.

review_title: Too much of a power struggle. People are not sure of their respective roles

Human Resources department personnel are not trained proper to handle staff issues, instead they pass you to one person or anothet without resolution.
